text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm live crisp peach cobbler that's
right we've done peach cobblers before
but never a crisp each cobbler and if
you're wondering why didn't I just call
it a peach crisp well I couldn't no
because that's what we call peach
crumbles I know it is a little confusing
but was not confusing is just how
absolutely gorgeous and delicious this
comes out and as advertised very crisp
so let's go ahead and get started with
the topping in the first step here is
we're going to smear together some
butter with some white sugar which is
super easy if your butters
room-temperature but mine was not it was
still pretty cold but that's fine if you
forget to take yours out of the fridge
like I did it will still work it's just
going to take you a lot longer and this
step will be significantly more annoying
but once we get it broken up and the
sugar kind of warms up the butter a
little it'll start to smear together
eventually about 4 to 5 minutes later
should come together and look something
like this alright basically a sugary
buttery paste and then once that's been
accomplished what we'll do is go ahead
and add some rolled oats as well as some
self-rising flour which as you know is
just regular flour with baking powder
and some salt in it and as usual I will
give you those measurements on the blog
and then we're basically just going to
repeat the last step by smearing and
Submission this stuff into the butter
sugar mixture and as you may have
noticed I've switched to a wooden spoon
which is a little more sturdy than the
rubber spatula I was using never be
afraid to switch tools especially when
you're cooking but no matter what
utensil you're using we're going to
basically do the same thing we'll just
keep working that flour and oats into
the butter and sugar until we have
something that sort of resembles
breadcrumbs the speaking of switch and
easier tools feel free to use your
electric mixer for this but you know
what it's summer and I want to look good
in a tight t-shirt so I decided to do
this by hand get a little bit of a
workout very little but a workout
nonetheless but anyway like I said we
will mix that together until we have
something that resembles breadcrumbs at
which point we will add the last
ingredient some whole milk or of course
a milk like substitute
so we'll go ahead and pour that in and
give it a mix and at first it's going to
seem kind of dry and crumbly like
something while we're on but just keep
stirring and you'll see it'll kind of
soften up and eventually after a minute
or two of stirring you should have
something that looks like this
all right sort of a very thick but
spreadable batter so that's looking
pretty good and what we'll do just set
that aside while we prep our peaches
which is going to be extra easy this
time because we're not going to make you
peel them so all we're going to do is
take a knife and split these in half and
to do that we'll simply cut in until the
knife hits the stone and you can really
go in anywhere but I generally try to
look for natural cleavage and slice in
right there and if we cut down to the
stone and just slice all the way around
by twisting the two halves that should
come apart just like that and we'll go
ahead and pull out the stone and then
what we'll do once our peaches have is
cut each half into four pieces which if
I'm asked correct that will give us
eight total and by the way if the skins
are going to bother you you certainly
could peel these but for me they don't
affect the taste and texture and I think
make the final color come out even more
beautiful not to mention I bet it's more
nutritious with them which of course is
the main reason you eat a peach cobbler
but anyway that's up to you you guys are
the teachers of your peaches but whether
you peel them or not once those are
transferred into our buttered baking
dish we'll go ahead and apply some
freshly grated lemon zest over the top
from exactly one fresh lemon I mean once
that's been accomplished we'll go ahead
and cut that in half and squeeze over
the juice and believe it or not that's
going to be it for the peach filling we
don't need any cornstarch we don't need
any sugar and then before we spread over
our topping what I like to do is just
settle these down which I could have
just done with my fingers but whenever I
can feature the freakishly small wooden
spoon I do
but anyway we'll give that a quick
once-over to make sure everything's sort
of settled evenly and we'll even give it
a little bit of a gentle pressing at
which point we can go ahead and transfer
on our topping just sort of plopping it
here and there and then we'll switch to
a butter knife to do the final spreading
as far as tips go here there aren't any
just spread it over don't overthink it
as long as the top is covered and it's
fairly even he did a good job and then
once our batter has been applied to the
top we have two things left to do we are
going to very generously sprinkle white
sugar all over the top and then once we
have our sugar applied things get a
little bit weird and by weird I mean wet
because the last step here is the
thoroughly moisten the top which I'm
going to do with a spray bottle well you
could do that by dripping over with a
pastry brush or your fingertips or even
a spoon would work oh by the way if you
use a squirt gun please put some fresh
water in there but something there's
probably from last summer but anyway one
way or another we're going to wet the
top thoroughly which is not that easy to
see from this angle so let's go for a
little bit of backlighting so you can
see just how much you need to apply
there we go and once our toppings been
sugared in moistened we're now ready to
bake so let's go ahead and transfer that
into the center of a 375 degree oven for
about 45 minutes or so or until the top
is beautifully browned and if
everything's gone according to plan it
should look something like this
it sure it's gorgeous and looks crispy
but is it really crispy well as you know
fork don't lie
oh yeah so thanks to that little sugar
water trick we did before we put it in
this thing develops literally a
glass-like crust so that was the good
news
the bad news is we can't eat this for a
while I think we need to let this cool
least a half hour to fully enjoy it so I
let mine cool about thirty minutes or so
before I grabbed a spoon to see how I
did and above and beyond the amazing
texture I just absolutely love how this
tastes I mean as you saw the filling was
incredibly simple just peaches and lemon
but when you combine it with that crispy
cobbler topping and that little bit of
oatmeal we have just an absolutely
beautiful thing to eat and it probably
is more than good enough just to eat out
of the dish like this but if you're a
real player we'll go ahead and transfer
that into a bowl and maybe top it with
some vanilla ice cream and that my
friends at least for me is like summer
in a bowl and I know I probably use that
expression for like half a dozen summer
recipes but in this case I mean it the
most oh and I should mention is you're
eating this you're probably going to
forget you didn't peel the peaches
because you really don't notice anything
texturally and that pigment from the
skin is actually given our syrup a
beautiful rosy color so not only did we
save time it actually made it look
better but anyway that's it what I'm
calling crisp peach cobbler I'm not sure
if it's going to be this upcoming fourth
of July holiday or some other occasion
this summer but at some point you're
going to be expected to bring something
to share and this could and probably
should be that thing I mean come on you
can't keep showing up with a bag of
chips and that's okay sometimes but you
get a step up your game if you want to
get invited to the good thickness and
this would help so I really do hope you
give this a try soon head over to food

amounts and more info as usual and as
